message: I know there is no definite answers but certainly there can be some pros and cons that can be highlighted.... YUI3 certainly has a steep learning curve compared to jQuery. But does jquery has a good future?
i still think jquery is a good bet. http://docs.jquery.com/Sites_Using_jQuery
@akshar100 jQuery is run by one person? http://jquery.org/team
jquery makes me feel like a ninja with a katana.

I will not get impressed by "sites using so and so" because sites like Google are so big that they must be using a lot of frameworks not just jQuery. Gmail's js engine is not jquery based it uses a custom Google js engine. Given that jQuery is run by a single person it is naive to think that large organizations will put much faith in jQuery while building serious products.

One specific thing that YUI lacks is the jQuery selector engine, which is far better than anyone elses, especially if you are working with XML. I tried to make some Strophe.js demos with the other libraries, and none of them could handle XML at all, unless you plugged in jQuery's selector engine instead of the default one.
@metajack could it be possible to integrate jQuery's engine <http://sizzlejs.com/> with YUI?
@ericmoritz thanks fo` sizzle ;) .js that is,.. at the end of the day though, the best tool is whichever tools that helps you do what you need/want. and at this moment, i think jQ > YUI
jQuery is bundled up with ASP.NET MVC. Microsoft is a 'large organization'.
RightJS all the way :-)

I really like YUI3, but it can feel a bit like a tank at times, for that reason jQ normally ends up winning out. Sizzle definitely doesn't hurt, despite it's occasional amazingly poor performance on seemingly simple selectors.
I think we'd all be happy if HTML5 included a native way to select elements by CSS rules.  I mean the browsers already know how to do it, why can we have access to that?
@ericmoritz https://developer.mozilla.org/En/DOM/Document.querySelector
@dag awesome, you rock.
@dag it only works with recent version of firefox, no?
@unwrangle See "Browser compatibility" further down the page.
@dag ah, thank you sir,.. was reading it from iPhone
@akshar100 jquery might well have a better future than yahoo.

I remember an interview with Resig when jQuery 1.3 rolled out that jQ was in use on over half the sites that Google was indexing. I'm much more concerned about Yahoo's future and thus the future of YUI than jQuery.
Looks like jQuery's Sizzle uses querySelector under the covers if it's available.
